data.title: Demonstration model for the ‘democratic deficit’
data.meta_description: A stalled proposal to extend minimum maternity leave across Europe exposes the technocrat-led EU bureaucracy that coordinates Union policies and (...)
data.text:
“It’s like searching for an aeroplane black box,” an EU parliamentary adviser told me. “It’s hard to identify leaders within the Council of the European Union capable of taking charge of the directive on maternity leave.” The draft, which was launched by the European Commission in 2008 and adopted by the European Parliament in 2010, seeks to increase the minimum maternity leave across the EU from 14 to 20 weeks. But it has been stalled for five years by the European Council, formed of ministers representing the member states. The lack of progress is blamed mostly on the little-known Committee of Permanent Representatives (Coreper).

Each of the 28 EU member states has a permanent representative in Brussels tasked with defending its interests. They meet on Coreper, aiming to achieve agreement between their governments on the issues being debated. But on maternity leave, Coreper hasn’t even started to reconcile national positions. “In spring 2015 the permanent representatives boycotted the meetings proposed by Belgian MEP Maria Arena (Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats), who has a keen interest in the issue, on the grounds that discussion was pointless without a consensus among the ministers,” says a Belgian member of the European civil service . It is not clear which states are blocking it and why. “Since 2010 we’ve been reduced to guesswork.”

The history of the directive shows the difficulties in establishing a European welfare state, another aspect of the “democratic deficit”. National governments find it convenient to blame Brussels, but they also take advantage of a system that fosters confusion over the division of responsibilities.

In 2008 the Commission, at the instigation of the EU social affairs commissioner Vladimír Špidla (Czech Republic), proposed to extend the minimum leave to 18 weeks, four weeks longer than provided by the 1992 directive, to follow the recommendations of the International Labour Organisation (ILO), fight birthrate decline across (...)
